It decreases with increasing amount of water vapour.

The dew point varies inversely with the temperature at a constant pressure.

options.text: the combined volume, at the combined temperature, becomes saturated and condensation occurs.
both air masses mix over a very long amount of time so that an adiabatic process is achieved.
there is a reservoir of humidity (such as a lake) nearby that provides for the necessary water droplets.
the temperature difference between the two air masses exceeds 20°C.

variant.question: What is the main result of the Fohn Effect?

options.text: Warmer and drier conditions on the leeward (downwind) side of the mountain than on the windward (upwind) side.
Warmer and drier conditions on the windward (upwind) side of the mountain than on the leeward (downwind) side.

variant.question: Define the Foehn

options.text: warm and dry air descending at the leeward side of the Alps.
cold and dry air descending at the leeward side of the Appalachian Mountains.
strong cold wind, mostly observed in the Rhone valley, blowing towards Southern France.
warm and dry air ascending on the west side of the Alps.
